A lot of twists and deaths. I feel like:
I loved the Force Awakens. Familiar though the plot was\, I felt that it was everything great about the original Star Wars updated and writ large for the 21st century. My expectations for The Last Jedi were huge\, but I was basically expecting to see all the promises of TFA fulfilled.

1) I wanted Kylo Ren to have at least one scene as grand and menacing as his introduction is TFA--striking down an old man in cold blood and then ordering the massacre of a whole village. 

What we got: Ren appears with the helmet for about 90 seconds and is parodied for it. The voice has been altered to sound weaker and more distorted\, reducing the menace. He gets no scenes of great evil or cruelty. What looks like the build to an amazing\, viscious confrontation with Luke turns out to be a sleight of hand. 

2) The Knights of Ren to make an appearance. I wanted that awesome scene in the rain from TFA to be fleshed out and explored here.

What we got: nothing.

3) Some kind of lightsaber duel.

What we got: nothing. One lightsaber battle with the praetorian guards\, but no one on one.

4) A backstory for Snoke and how he influenced Ben Solo to the Dark Side.

What we got: indirect verbal narrarive.

5) More gritty scenes that portray the Stormtroopers as fearsome\, as in the opening sequence of TFA.

What we got: virtually no trooper vs anyone action. It's all star fighter battles.

6) A darker storyline.

What we got: self-parody\, Disneyfication and half a dozen new cgi cutesy creatures.

7) To discover the significance of Rey's lineage and possible connection to Ren.

What we got: Rey's parents are nobody and she has no prior connection to Ren.

I could go on. But essentially\, this film failed to fulfil the promises\, tone and set up TFA. It dispensed with the mysteries and the answers to those mysteries that would have surprised and delughted fans.

It's a well-shot\, Star Wars-themed children's film. Very light-hearted. A mixture of Harry Potter\, Twilight\, Toy Story and Avengers. 

It is not a weighty\, darker sequel that adequately develops the premises and themes of TFA (although the Rey / Ren development has some limited merit -- ultimately comes off hackneyed and hollow\, though). It left me and countless long term Star Wars fan bitterly disappointed\, empty and deflated.

This is the only Star Wars film that has filled me with horror and disappointment as it draws to a close\, because it had so spectacularly failed to meet expectation or grab my imagination. Its faux-depth and self-parody undermine it and feel like a slap in the face.
